subject: Entrepreneurship
title: The Power Law: Why VCs Bet on Outliers
description: A quick, practical guide to The Power Law: Why VCs Bet on Outliers.

hook.text: Peter Thiel invested $500K in Facebook. It returned more than every other investment in Founders Fund combined.

buildup.text: Startup returns follow a power law: a tiny number of investments generate almost all the profits.

discovery.text: This means VCs must swing for home runs. A 2x return is actually a failure in VC math.

twist.text: Founders who want a comfortable $5M exit don't fit the VC model. It's billion or bust.

climax.text: The best VC funds have 1-2 investments that return the entire fund. Everything else is noise.

punchline.text: In venture capital, average is the enemy of great.

quiz.question: What does the power law mean for venture capital?
options: A tiny number of investments generate nearly all of a fund's profits
Returns are evenly distributed across all portfolio companies
Larger investments always produce larger returns
